body:
Ideas for digging:
- comment out the ECDSA additions to see if they are in fact the culprit
  - Perhaps also disable the ECDSA kex on the server so it's not offering it
- if that doesn't do it, look at the other changes in 1.12 (which should really only be the 'env' support, seems unlikely.)

Remote chance it's related to #175, too. However that says zip about Paramiko-to-Paramiko comparisons, only Paramiko-vs-OpenSSH, implying it's a pre-existing condition and not a regression as this ticket appears to be.

Part of the issue is caused by trying to hash hostnames already hashed when loading known hosts files. Patch submitted as pull request #272. Remaining slowdown happens when loading ecdsa keys from the known hosts file

Hello!

On python 2.7.5+

It'd be great to have an option to disable ECDSA. (Or delegate it to a C extension if a suitable one is available.)

python -m trace -g --trace --ignore-module=numbertheory,threading,sre_compile,sre,sre_parse,six,HMAC,rsakey,hashalgo,ellipticcurve,util,hostkeys,SHA,base64,py3compat,message,**init**,ecdsakey,keys,ecdsa  remote-env-test.py

```
1.83 client.py(152):                 self._system_host_keys.load(filename)
 --- modulename: dsskey, funcname: __init__
9.34 dsskey.py(41):         self.p = None
```

So it took 8 seconds with tracing, and about 5 with just /usr/bin/time.

```
4.66user 0.02system 0:05.15elapsed 90%CPU (0avgtext+0avgdata 13872maxresident)k
0inputs+0outputs (0major+5404minor)pagefaults 0swaps
```

Here's remote-env-test.py

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
import plumbum.cli
from plumbum.machines.paramiko_machine import ParamikoMachine

m = ParamikoMachine('someserver.int.example-corp.com')

print(m["ls"]("-alh"))
```
Remaining slowdown after #272 is caused by this issue: https://github.com/warner/python-ecdsa/issues/19

Thanks for digging, @sigmunau! Sounds like there isn't a ton we can do on our end until that is fixed? I'm open to suggestions, though re @PAStheLoD I'm not sure that entirely disabling ECDSA host keys is viable (nor am I aware of any C-extensions - might consider preferentially loading one should they exist.)

Perhaps an opt-in setting for "skip ECDSA host keys in my known_hosts, I promise not to try connecting to any of those hosts" but even that's kinda stretching it, IMO - too many options is bad and this feels like an edge case (especially if upstream can fix it somehow.)

There are a few potential ones ( https://github.com/kmackay/easy-ecc https://polarssl.org/discussions/generic/ecdsa-usage-example https://www.openssl.org/docs/crypto/ecdsa.html ) but these need to be wrapped with Cython or cffi or at least cuddled with ctypes, probably quite nasty stuff, but for efficient number crunching I don't have other ideas.

Anyhow, thanks for caring about this.

@PAStheLoD You are ignoring the ecdsa module when running your trace. And the trace seems to show all the time being spent in dsskey.py, so your issue is probably something completely different. If you have loads of hashed host key entries in your known hosts file you could potentially speed things up by applying #272
The "ignored part", is just the point_is_valid calls, http://pastebin.com/9WFmvvfd , and I have 72 ecdsa-sha2-nistp256 keys in my known_hosts.

While investigating excessive CPU usage by fabric, I found that in my environment pycrypto was using the _slowmath.py implementation for RSA/DSA and that was causing excessive CPU usage.  After installing the gmp-devel package (CentOS) and rebuilding PyCrypto against it (to get the _fastmath path active) I saw a 70% drop in CPU usage from fabric.  It's still higher than I recall from older versions of paramiko but this change has solved many of the performance problems I've had.
For the reference, all my tests were done using fastmath.

issue.title: Don't validate points in known_hosts ECDSA keys

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
Point validation is really expensive and apparently unnecessary when
we already trust the keys in our known_hosts file.

With my current known_hosts file of 657 keys, this reduces the time
taken to complete a remote task in fabric from 24 seconds to 7 seconds.

This requires python-ecdsa >= 0.11.

Closes #270.

body:
I can confirm this slowdown with ECDSA keys. I have 187 ECDSA keys in my known_hosts file. Paramiko spends ~7 seconds in the point validation, more precisely in the "double" function: 

  ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.000    0.000   10.187   10.187 ./push-config.py:3()
        1    0.000    0.000    9.157    9.157 ./push-config.py:15(push_config)
        1    0.000    0.000    9.157    9.157 ncclient/manager.py:73(connect_ssh)
        1    0.000    0.000    8.551    8.551 ncclient/transport/ssh.py:117(load_known_hosts)
        1    0.007    0.007    8.551    8.551 paramiko/hostkeys.py:79(load)
     1215    0.008    0.000    7.807    0.006 paramiko/hostkeys.py:297(from_line)
      187    0.002    0.000    7.671    0.041 paramiko/ecdsakey.py:42(__init__)
      187    0.003    0.000    7.664    0.041 ecdsa/keys.py:32(from_string)
      187    0.001    0.000    7.656    0.041 ecdsa/ecdsa.py:190(point_is_valid)
      374    0.000    0.000    7.654    0.020 ecdsa/ellipticcurve.py:140(__rmul__)
      567    0.060    0.000    7.654    0.013 ecdsa/ellipticcurve.py:109(__mul__)
    56661    5.479    0.000    7.081    0.000 ecdsa/numbertheory.py:186(inverse_mod)
    47872    0.265    0.000    6.401    0.000 ecdsa/ellipticcurve.py:149(double)

Going to close this since it sounds like #272 and #298 wrap up the bulk of the speed problems from ECDSA support. They are both in Reviewed state and will go out in the next release cycle once I complete some more ticket triage. Users will need to nab the 1.15 release for the full fix as #298 requires dependency tweaking and isn't appropriate for a bugfix release.

Thanks again to everybody who reported & troubleshot this :)
fyi both bug and bug fix verified in #370

issue.title: Document PyCrypto's hilarious/sad slowmath vs fastmath BS

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
## Background

While investigating some slow connection times for my employer, I narrowed our particular slowdown to public key authentication, and then specifically to the creation of the RSA algorithm object based on the key in question (a 2048-bit RSA key).

Searching around for why this operation would be slow led me to https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/270#issuecomment-37074306 which mentions the hitherto unknown to me 'slowmath' concept in PyCrypto.

More digging found this: https://github.com/dlitz/pycrypto/blob/7acba5f3a6ff10f1424c309d0d34d2b713233019/lib/Crypto/Util/number.py#L39-L53

tl;dr you need `libgmp-dev`, `gmp-devel` or similar installed to trigger building/using of this `_fastmath.so` module; otherwise, you get a significantly slower Python implementation of the same logic.

In my local testing, a key that takes on average 2.5-3.5s to generate its `RSA` object with slowmath, takes only 0.5-0.9s with fastmath. Presumably all sorts of other operations (like regular transit encryption, vs authentication signing) are faster in this setup as well - I am still testing.
## To do
- [x] Add install documentation noting that if you install `libgmp-dev` etc, you may see significantly faster operations.
- [ ] ~~Doublecheck exactly what appears faster so I can quantify that a little better~~ _meh_
- [x] Sanity check whether the average distro-distributed/built paramiko/pycrypto seems to be enabling fastmath or not, so we can quantify whether this mostly impacts from-source users or not. (I'd guess 'yes'.)
